results.title: Thomas Alva Edison
results.brief_description: After seeing Eadweard Muybridge’s and Étienne-Jules Marey’s photography, Thomas Edison charged Scottish inventor William Dickson with developing the Kinetoscope, a large cabinet housing 50-foot loops of film that showed short movies on everything from dancing women to boxing cats.

constellations_primary.name: Thomas Edison
constellations_primary.description: Thomas Edison helped establish cinema as an art-form and mass entertainment. Many of his early films were short and showed everyday activities like riding a bicycle.

results.description: Thomas Edison daydreamed at school. Though his teachers were unimpressed, the American inventor later imagined numerous innovative devices and processes. He improved the telegraph system and created the first commercially practical light bulb, as well as the phonograph sound recorder. After seeing Eadweard Muybridge’s and Étienne-Jules Marey’s photography, Edison charged Scottish inventor William Dickson with developing the Kinetoscope, a large cabinet housing 50-foot loops of film that showed short movies on everything from dancing women to boxing cats. One film was Fred Ott’s Sneeze (1894), which, like many of the films, Dickson produced with another Edison invention, the Kinetograph, the first motion-picture camera. These inventions contributed to filmmaking as we know it – and prove it pays to daydream.
description_for_label: Thomas Edison daydreamed at school. Though his teachers were unimpressed, the American inventor later imagined numerous innovative devices and processes. He improved the telegraph system and created the first commercially practical light bulb, as well as the phonograph sound recorder. After seeing Eadweard Muybridge’s and Étienne-Jules Marey’s photography, Edison charged Scottish inventor William Dickson with developing the Kinetoscope, a large cabinet housing 50-foot loops of film that showed short movies on everything from dancing women to boxing cats. One film was Fred Ott’s Sneeze (1894), which, like many of the films, Dickson produced with another Edison invention, the Kinetograph, the first motion-picture camera. These inventions contributed to filmmaking as we know it – and prove it pays to daydream.

results.title: The Story of the Kelly Gang
results.credit_line: Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia.
results.brief_description: Produced in Melbourne in 1906, The Story of the Kelly Gang is the world’s first feature-length film. While most movies of its era only ran for about 12 minutes, Charles Tait’s bushranger epic went for over an hour.

constellations_primary.name: Outlawed
constellations_primary.description: From The Story of the Kelly Gang to Sweet Country, this Constellation explores bushrangers, samurai and bandits.

constellations_other.name: Crime doesn't pay
constellations_other.description: Ned Kelly's famous armour has appeared in many films, but the criminal myth speaks to how audiences have always been captivated by true-crime stories, from the beginning of cinema to today.

constellations_other.name: Bell & Howell Projector 621: This picture has been edited for content
constellations_other.description: The Bell & Howell-Gaumont Model 621 projector was originally used entertain the shearers on a sheep farm in South Australia with the films screened sometimes edited for distribution.

constellations_other.name: True blue, true crime
constellations_other.description: Robert Connolly's The Dry is a recent Australian crime blockbuster, but the writer, director and producer's first film (and first crime film) connects to a longstanding tradition of true-blue crime stories from some of our greatest filmmakers.

results.description:
Produced in Melbourne in 1906, The Story of the Kelly Gang is the world’s first feature-length film. While most movies of its era only ran for about 12 minutes, Charles Tait’s bushranger epic went for over an hour. But it wasn’t just the longest film by time: it was literally ‘the longest film ever made’, at a staggering 4,000 feet of celluloid.

Its popularity was also staggering, so much so that in 1914 the New South Wales government banned the production of bushranger films, believing that The Story of the Kelly Gang influenced rising crime. That’s debatable, but the film’s influence on other filmmakers isn’t.
description_for_label:
Produced in Melbourne in 1906, The Story of the Kelly Gang is the world’s first feature-length film. While most movies of its era only ran for about 12 minutes, Charles Tait’s bushranger epic went for over an hour. But it wasn’t just the longest film by time: it was literally ‘the longest film ever made’, at a staggering 4,000 feet of celluloid.

Its popularity was also staggering, so much so that in 1914 the New South Wales government banned the production of bushranger films, believing that The Story of the Kelly Gang influenced rising crime. That’s debatable, but the film’s influence on other filmmakers isn’t.
results.credit_line_for_label: Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia.

results.title: The Road Warrior publicity images
results.brief_description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Bursting with stunning practical effects, explosive set pieces and iconic costumes, the original Mad Max trilogy (1979–85) cemented its place in pop culture before roaring back to life 30 years later.

results.title: The Power of Love
results.creator_credit: Harry K. Fairall and Nat G. Deverich
results.brief_description: The first feature 3D motion picture screened for a commercial audience was The Power of Love (1922), which used the red-and-green anaglyph system that most people associate with 3D. Audiences looked through red-and-green glasses at two film strips, recorded and projected in each colour.

constellations_primary.name: The power of alternate endings
constellations_primary.description: This Constellation about alternate perspectives, dream states, sitcoms and spin-offs was made by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies student Daniel Bryan.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Harry K. Fairall and Nat G. Deverich
results.description:
Though experiments into stereoscopic movies started back in 1889, filmmaker Edwin S Porter projected the first 3D test film in 1915. He used the red-and-green anaglyph system that most people associate with 3D. Audiences looked through red-and-green glasses at two film strips, recorded and projected in each colour, that gave the illusion of depth when superimposed.

The same system was used for The Power of Love (1922), the first feature 3D motion picture screened for a commercial audience. And 3D wasn’t that film’s only innovation: viewers could choose different endings by peering through only the red or green lens. It was the only film released using the Fairall-Elder stereoscopic camera pictured here.
description_for_label:
Though experiments into stereoscopic movies started back in 1889, filmmaker Edwin S Porter projected the first 3D test film in 1915. He used the red-and-green anaglyph system that most people associate with 3D. Audiences looked through red-and-green glasses at two film strips, recorded and projected in each colour, that gave the illusion of depth when superimposed.

The same system was used for The Power of Love (1922), the first feature 3D motion picture screened for a commercial audience. And 3D wasn’t that film’s only innovation: viewers could choose different endings by peering through only the red or green lens. It was the only film released using the Fairall-Elder stereoscopic camera pictured here.

results.title: The Favourite costume sketch of Queen Anne's robes
results.brief_description:
Costume designer Sandy Powell begins her design process with the script. Once she knows the story, she consults with directors on how they envision the characters. Then she fills books - divided into chapters on each character - with research images before she sources fabric. Choosing the kinds of fabric she will use is one of the most important parts of Powell’s process – the fabric gives her the idea for her costumes.    

In The Favourite (2018), Powell uses historically accurate silhouettes but modern materials like second-hand denim, fake leather and vinyl. While you might think costume designers always sketch their designs first, many don’t, including Powell, who dives straight into creating the costumes. She only makes the sketches after she knows what the costumes look like and the actors have tested them.

results.title: The Blind Man of Siloam lantern slides
results.brief_description: The Salvation Army ran Australia’s first production company, The Limelight Department. They produced hundreds of scenes and stories by photographing actors in sets and costumes, printing these scenes on slides and then hand-colouring them before staging performances like The Blind Man of Siloam.

constellations_primary.name: Religion, cinema and censorship
constellations_primary.description: Religious narratives and themes have a complicated relationship with censorship, with creators pushing the boundaries for better or worse.

results.description: The Salvation Army isn’t just a part of Melbourne’s social fabric – it’s also an integral part of moving-image history. The Salvation Army ran Australia’s first production company, The Limelight Department. They produced hundreds of scenes and stories by photographing actors in elaborate sets and costumes, printing these scenes on slides and then hand-colouring them in the department’s Bourke Street studio. The Blind Man of Siloam shows how this technique re-created ancient locations from hand-painted backgrounds. The department’s most famous show, Soldiers of the Cross, featured over 200 slides projected from multiple lanterns, as well as hymns, music, motion-picture segments and rousing narration.
description_for_label: The Salvation Army isn’t just a part of Melbourne’s social fabric – it’s also an integral part of moving-image history. The Salvation Army ran Australia’s first production company, The Limelight Department. They produced hundreds of scenes and stories by photographing actors in elaborate sets and costumes, printing these scenes on slides and then hand-colouring them in the department’s Bourke Street studio. The Blind Man of Siloam shows how this technique re-created ancient locations from hand-painted backgrounds. The department’s most famous show, Soldiers of the Cross, featured over 200 slides projected from multiple lanterns, as well as hymns, music, motion-picture segments and rousing narration.

results.title: TERROR NULLIUS Acquisition
results.material_description: VHS case, hard drive with USB adaptor, paper ceritificate of authenticity
results.brief_description: The acquisition of time-based media artworks requires our collection team to develop a host of preservation strategies that often go unseen by visitors. These strategies include the receipt of master moving-image files and provenance documentation. Soda_Jerk’s acquisition, presented here, displays their political and humorous sense of creativity as the humble certificate of authenticity and external hard drive packaging get a playful overhaul, which reflects the subversive nature of the artwork, TERROR NULLIUS.
